Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Conceptualizing An Institute for Empowering Long Tail Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of NSF-funded research occurs in small and medium-sized laboratories (SMLs) that often comprise a single PI and a few students and postdocs. For these small teams, the growing importance of cyberinfrastructure and its applications in discovery and innovation is as much problem as opportunity. With limited resources and expertise, even simple data discovery, collection, analysis, management, and sharing tasks are difficult. An unfortunate consequence is that in this "long tail" of science, modern computational methods often are not exploited, much valuable data goes unshared, and too much time is consumed by routine tasks. To date, research investments in science cyberinfrastructure have disproportionately emphasized big science projects, providing tools for use by IT staff and technology savvy researchers rather than complete applications consumable by end users. This projects' goal is to lay a foundation for a more balanced research agenda by focusing exclusively on the needs of SMLs.

This Software Institute Conceptualization project aims to determine whether these obstacles to discovery and innovation can be overcome via the use of software as a service (SaaS) methods. Such methods have proven immensely effective for small and medium businesses due to their ability to deliver advanced capabilities while streamlining the user experience and achieving economies of scale. To determine whether similar benefits can apply for SMLs, the project team will engage with multiple science communities to identify science practices, match science practices against candidate SaaS offerings, and evaluate business models that could permit sustainable development of those offerings. The outcome of this process is intended to be a compelling and competitive strategic plan for an NSF Software Innovation and Sustainability Institute that both meets immediate needs of the initial science communities and provides a basis for a new, more cost-effective method of addressing cyberinfrastructure needs across all NSF directorates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was charged with “organizing an interdisciplinary community and understanding their software requirements and challenges.” The intent was that the resulting community should benefit from the establishment of an NSF Scientific Software Innovation Institute focused on their software requirements and challenges. We proposed to develop a plan for an Institute for Enabling Long Tail Research (IELTR) aimed at leveraging the power of SaaS methods to support a broad spectrum of SML researchers.

Finding 1: There is no single SML community that can be organized, in the manner envisioned by NSF, to determine community software requirements and challenges. SML researchers constitute the majority of all NSF-funded (and indeed, non-NSF-funded) researchers. They come from a wide variety of disciplinary, scientific, and institutional backgrounds. It does not appear feasible to organize them to determine requirements or to shape consensus around priorities for technology support and development.

Finding 2: SaaS technologies can provide tremendous benefit to SMLs. For the reasons noted in Finding 1, this observation is not based on any comprehensive survey of SMLs. Rather, it is derived from: (a) studies of SaaS adoption and impacts within small and medium businesses; (b) the consistent message received from SMLs that IT tasks, particularly relating to research data management, are a major challenge; and (c) positive responses to our experiments with Globus and SQLShare.

Finding 3: In the absence of an SML community that can be consulted, an Institute for Enabling Long-tail Research would require a different organization than one designed to support a specific community. It might, for example, provide access to enabling capabilities, support many experiments, and sustain those that show usage as evidenced via metrics such as number of users and subscription revenues.

Our study consistently indicates that there is a potential for consolidation of the overall physical resources required for research and infrastructure in the USA. Specifically, researchers can find greater value in shared, commercial resources such as Amazon, Google, etc. and shared, non-commercial resources such as Globus, XSEDE, Open Science Grid, etc. SaaS and PaaS products should allow researchers to accomplish their work without requiring as many resources owned and operated by their local institutions or their own personal facilities. Particularly attractive features of shared services include: low cost of adoption, low cost of ownership and lack of long-term commitment.

Another benefit of facility consolidation is that a greater percentage of researchers will have access to best-of-breed facilities. More pointedly, fewer researchers will be forced to rely on locally developed, non-professional, higher-cost facilities. As shared facilities become more useful to researchers, host institutions will have less need to staff and house IT facilities.

Our results also suggest interesting directions for sustainability via engagement with institutional infrastructure providers. Globus experimented during this period with both institutional and individual subscriptions. The former gained a lot of traction, while the latter did not. It appears that campus IT organizations are motivated to both increase service to their constituents and reduce demands on their time by subscribing to a service that contributes to both goals. The UW team, meanwhile, worked to transfer responsibility for operating their SQLshare SaaS research platform to University IT Operations.
